instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has about 0.3v in <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Good morning, I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has about 0.3v in <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>, is smc dead or <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has about 0.3v in <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: First the basic voltages on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Is DCIN present is 3V42 even present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has about 0.3v in <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: it's present, heating SMC area the board started to work again, so I supposed it was a dead smc. I replaced the smc and still same problem. Boards boot only heating smc area

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has about 0.3v in <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Pull up resistor on ACOK line bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has about 0.3v in <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: please, can you tell which resistor should I check?  <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> is 2k

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has about 0.3v in <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Sorry problem not solved. <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is 1.4v instead of 3v. <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> is present, already replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> 2 times.  If I press with a finger under <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area boards boots even if <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is low

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has about 0.3v in <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Value of <RESISTOR>R5087</RESISTOR> and resistance to GND on the ACOK line?
